While picking up my wife from work yesterday, she pointed my nose towards the cover article of this months University of Leeds Reporter. The article looks at some ongoing work looking at littorina saxatilis, a sea snail, and how new species are appearing in certain localites. 
 
 Luckly for my fingers there is an online version of this article:
 
 Evolution at a snail's pace: UoLR July 2004 
 
 
 While not very technical I thought this is of interest as it is an example of the a study looking at evolutionary mechanisms operating today where they can be directly studied.
 
 :xcensored emoticon_angry :xbanghead emoticon_xkill

post_info.post_title: Evolution at a snails pace...... evolution in action

This is awesome.
 
 Not only are they showing direct evidence of natural selection in action (crab resistors vs. crab avoiders) but they are witnessing speciation as a direct result.
 
 Totally cool. emoticon_xgood
Very good article, thanks for posting that. It will be interesting to see what the future holds.
And a dandy example of disruptive selection, where the extremes of a population are favored, as opposed to the mean. This is usually rather rapid, and hence it's more often noticed than other kinds.

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Evolution at a snails pace...... evolution in action
